content.body: These web standards are open, reliable, highly secure, and only supported by Safari.
I accidentally opened the chatlogs from 2008 instead of 2010, and I didn't notice for a while
Man, wth.  4 freaking "google promo" emails have gotten through the spamblocker today.
google knows your spamblocker
be afraid
I'm trying to understand what the validation errors at http://validator.nu/?doc=https%3A%2F%2Feyeasme.com%2FJoe%2FMathML%2FHTML5%2Fextras.html
the initial error is because you can't have an HTML img element in SVG content served as text/html
right?
er, make that MathML content
I thought for this case the parser is supposed to just ignore the img, then pop the open MathML annotation-xml element from the stack and proceed from there
tries to decode http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Jun/0001.html to work out what the reason is for removing the text
does anybody know what the actual reason behind the "widespread belief" that the paragraph is harmful might be?
nothing seems to actually explain what the reason is...
huh? :)
Hixie: ?
you there?
here
cool
is there anyone wanting to do websocket serving in browsers?
I know the peer to peer provisions got removed
but I have some big plans for doing web p2p
the peer to peer stuff got moved to a differnet part of the spec
but it's still there
ohh it is?
search for PeerToPeer
I didn't see it anymore
it's very immature so far
yeah anyway I could help?
sorry, "peer-to-peer", not "PeerToPeer"
I'm really serious about p2p on web as a platform
interface name is ConnectionPeer
I think it's the only way to attempt to avoid firewalls/packet inspection properly heh
i envisage some sort of mechanism that would let peers connect to each other
what about doing that coding in javascript
but with the protocol defined in a spearate working group
coding?
I mean relying on client coding to handle peer connections
just keep the spec real simple
maybe even utilize websockets?
websockets isn't really applicable here
there's nothing about web sockets that makes sense for peer to peer
well just being about to serve websockets from a browser should be real simple to do
about/able
it would also not solve like 90% of the use cases :-)
it's like 5 lines in nodejs
like, you wouldn't be able to connect to it
i think we need a much better solution than that
can't we build on websockets?
I know we need a firewall breaker utilizing upnp or some other methods
but that can be subject to browser implementation
i see nothing in websockets that would be even remotely useful in doing this
sad to hear that
I think websockets is a nice simple protocol
it'd be nice to have a simple low overhead protocol even one already implemented in some form to use and get p2p jump started
I guess it can be coded as a plugin for now
see if anyone finds it useful
websockets is a very simple protocol, yes -- it has like three features: a handshake with origin protection, a client/server architecture, and framing for text
for peer-to-peer we don't have origins, the architecture is client/client, and the framing needs to support video.
it's like completely different.
websockets 2.0 :)
i don't think trying to use websockets is a helpful way forward here
it's just a simple way forward
I don't think it's bad to be able to share text/base64 coded images
if people start sending base64 encoded data over 8-bit-safe network infrastructure, we've failed.
well could websockets be expanded upon and be made binary safe
man, you're like someone with a hammer who sees everything as a nail :-)
we should design solutions to fit the problems we have
not try to take our existing solutions and bend them to all similar problems
I like extending solutions we have already
websockets is pretty new and it'd be nice to boost it up :)
no, it really wouldn't :-)
I'm actually conforming to the web since I see it as the main future of transporting most content
it would just make it be more complex
why can't we just make a more appropriate protocol for this use case?
really I say screw the web even and let's make more and more efficient protocols tasked for the problem at hand
(or use one of the many existing ones?)
anyway
well I'd like the traffic to go across regular protocols/ports
ok then I see you don't believe in the same direction
could you point me to the new section with the peer to peer area?
http://www.mail-archive.com/whatwg⊙lwo/msg19815.html
I guess there have already been discussions on this
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#peer-to-peer-connections
really big on video
yeah it was originally intended for video conferencing
ahh ok
I don't like the third party server concept
we need it, no other way to do double NAT traversal
hybrid p2p
nat traversal can be done with upnp right?
jwm: not on my network
upnp is disabled on my router (because it's a HUGE security hole)
secure when your computers can be trusted :)
(which is never)
heh
raham: aah! I forgot about sectioning root. doh
scotfl: what was your comment on sectioning root in reference to?
When dealing with legacy systems that depend on RTMP for live streaming of events, is there any support for showing these streams in HTML5?
Hixie, Requiem 1.9.4 is out. This should work with iTunes 9.1.1
